There is some pretty interesting research into viral triggers for the onset of type 1 DM!

Prednisone?

Type 1 diabetics often lose weight before being diagnosed because they aren't producing any meaningful amount of insulin so they are not storing or using any of the carbohydrates that they are taking in.
Type 2 diabetics can make insulin but they don't respond to it as well so their blood sugars are elevated but they are still using some of the carbohydrates that they are taking in, so they probably won't drop weight.

Ok so both of them work to reduce pain and fever but ibuprofen (Advil) is an NSAID (non steroidal anti inflammatory) so it will also reduce swelling which makes it more effective for things like sprains and muscle strains where a lot of the pain is caused by inflammation. Acetaminophen (Tylenol) doesn't do jack for inflammation
Acetaminophen (Tylenol) and ibuprofen (Advil) both work by blocking COX enzymes in the brain which inhibits the production of some prostaglandins. Prostaglandins do a lot of good, helpful things but some cause pain and inflammation after cellular injury by a whole bunch of mechanisms sat the site of injury and in the peripheral nervous system (and a bit in the central nervous system) and they act on the hypothalamus (body thermostat) to raise body temperature which is what causes someone to spike a fever.
Ibuprofen is a nonselective COX inhibitor which means it blocks the production of prostaglandins that act in the peripheral and central nervous systems to cause pain, fever and inflammation (yay!) BUT it also blocks the production of prostaglandins that protect the stomach lining which is why taking a lot of ibuprofen can lead to ulcers and even normal doses can cause stomach upset in some people.
Tylenol doesn't do much for the prostaglandins that act in the peripheral nervous system so it doesn't really do anything to reduce inflammation (which is what causes a lot of pain at the site of injuries) but it works in the central nervous system and effectively reduces fever and the sensation of pain that isn't caused by swelling. Also it can majorly fuck up your liver if you take too much so beware.
I probably got something wrong (please correct me) but yeah.
Yup, they are the same thing one is just more descriptive/the term more commonly used by professionals.

I am spoiled in this regard, the floor I'm currently on for my rotations has clinical pharmacists on the unit full time to deal with our med issues (we are a med surg floor that takes transplant patients stepping down from SICU, renal/liver failure patients, organ rejections, some GI surgeries and dialysis patients, plus some other more standard med surg issues)
6:1 and we are all on the same unit so our instructor can give us a lot of individual attention which is really nice.

Honestly, I like to think that I am reasonably self aware of my limits and I fully acknowledge that there is an insane amount of information that I do not know and many skills/pearls that will only come with time and clinical experience. I do enjoy reading and researching topics that may be beyond my scope but that is because I'm a nerd and I have no delusions that as a 19 year old sophomore in college I have any use for this information beyond personal enrichment and sometimes getting a deeper understanding of things I am learning in lectures.

I had braces, expanders and headgear for 5 flipping years as a kid but my lower jaw grew a but and that coupled with my abnormally small lower jaw has left me back where I started with an underbite.

My mom did the same thing, but she called it a "good manners bite"
I still eat a pretty limited diet when left to my own devices but the things I like are pretty healthy since I was never allowed to limit myself to "kid food" (I could live off of raw carrots, steamed broccoli, sweet potatoes and salmon or chicken) and I am willing to try anything at least once because worst case scenario, I don't like it and life goes on.

Yeah learning to swim just isn't a thing in a lot of black communities among well off, educated people learning to swim just isn't seen as a priority or "life skill" along the same lines as riding a bike or driving.
I'm biracial and almost none of my black cousins know how to swim even though they are upper middle class and have the time, money and facilities to learn. They mostly cite not wanting to damage their hair as the reason but it still strikes me as odd that these people who take Caribbean vacations and live in country club neighborhoods with pools never felt the need to spring for a few swimming lessons.

My parents did the same thing with me! I was super shy and completely incapable of advocating for myself so they would put me in lower pressure situations where I would have to ask for help to prepare me for situations with teachers or employers later in life.
It sucked because I was so painfully shy I would be crying/shaking but my parents always had me do something like ask the person at our local bookstore for a recommendation then they would buy me the book so there was a built in reward.
The only reason I ever remember the number for IT at my hospital is because it spells out 'my PC"

Really struggling with my eating disorder and it is starting to scare me that I can't seem to break myself out of this cycle.
I feel so out of control with my symptom use and I don't know what to do; my team thinks that I need inpatient (which isn't an option) but I'm stuck in this cycle of restricting, purging and occasionally bingeing which I've never dealt with before now. In the end it all comes down to my fear of gaining weight; I don't think that I need to and ultimately I know that this fear is what is driving my behavior. My team thinks that I need to gain and even if that is true I just don't feel like I'm in a place to make that happen and in the grand scheme of things I don't think it should be at the top of my treatment priorities. I know that my symptom use is a major problem but I'm really struggling to feel a sense of urgency because I feel like my body is still able to cope which i know is so incredibly stupid.
I had therapy and a dietician appointment yesterday and they were both like we don't know what to do with you and I'm trying to get in my full meal plan today but its not even morning snack time yet and I just feel fat and overwhelmed and I can't see why I need to do this.
I'm just so frustrated and done with myself; I hate the way that I'm living but I don't want to gain weight and I feel like I'm "too fat" to justify as eating the amount that they want me to.

Same here!

It's even more awkward because I go to a big university with a well regarded nursing program and a medical school so I regularly interact with med students.

Food and gas.
I'm really lucky that I got almost a full academic scholarship to school that includes housing so my parents are willing/able to cover most of my books and fees that aren't covered by the scholarship, but I decided not to work during the school year so right now I'm living off of what I saved by working full time all summer and spending almost nothing.
It is completely doable since I only have to worry about day to day expenses (copays on therapist/doctor/dietician visits and meds, groceries, gas for my car) and all of the big expenses like insurance and tuition are covered I just have to be thrifty and make sure I keep track of where my money is going because when you have $40 a week (on average) little expenditures can add up.

I like to compliment people on things that I can tell that they work hard for or care about whether its a skill, progress towards a goal or even just their passion for a topic.

I have sympathy for people who live in poverty or other shitty situations when it comes to poor dietary choices; sure, it is possible to eat well for cheap but I can also see that food is a cheap way to make yourself feel (temporarily) good and when you work a shitty, low paying stressful job it can be hard to turn down the one "luxury" you can consistently indulge in.

A lot of it comes down to planning as well.
I'm not going to pretend that I'm poor or have any idea what it is really like to struggle financially but as a college student who doesn't work during the school year I have to keep myself to a pretty tight budget during the school year and I eat pretty well on the cheap. I do have a car and access to a pretty decent sized refrigerator and freezer but I save a lot of money by sticking to my cheap essentials and only buying things when they are on sale (I stock up when I can get a good price).
Sure, its a bit repetitive but I don't mind eating the same thing for most meals if it allows me to have money to spend on other nonessential things (and gas. I am very grateful that my parents got me a car as my graduation gift/reward for getting a full academic scholarship but good grief I can't afford to only get 20mpg)

Atypical anorexia is a legitimate condition; people can develop the symptoms of anorexia (restriction etc.) at higher weights and even though they lose a lot very quickly they may not dip into the underweight category before doctors/therapists become concerned and diagnose them with an eating disorder. A lot of people with atypical anorexia are at the low end of the healthy range.

YES!
I also don't like that they seem to want the entire world to change to accommodate the neurosis of people with eating disorders. Yes, people should be considerate but as someone with an eating disorder, I see it as my problem not something that everyone else needs to be protecting me from. People with eating disorders are a pretty small portion of the population so while things like nutrition labels on menus may challenge some of us they either help or do nothing for the vast majority of the population so we should be the ones learning to cope.

Same here!
My prof is actually a researcher whose primary area of interest is obesity prevention/weight loss so any fatlogic gets shut down right quick.
People talk crap but I've never actually heard about her behaving badly or treating people poorly.

Yeah we are taught to ask if a patient has sex with men, women or both because there are people who may have sex with someone of their sme gender but wouldn't identify them self as gay.
Its actually pretty interesting, there have been studies about the different responses that are given when this question is phrased in different ways.

Heck, I eat in public a lot because I'm busy and need to pack my snacks/meals to get through the day.

For my service unit it is 12 dollars per year per kid to be a Girl Scout. Some troops do charge dues but it varies, and honestly cookies really don't bring in much money at all (troops get like 55 cents for every box that they sell).
Buying cookies also helps the service units do things like pay for lower income kids to go to camp or other big events that they wouldn't be able to afford and help fund troops in poor schools where parents might not have the time or energy to start them.
Same here, I don't have any advice but I can offer you an internet hug!

I've been doing that but then I just end up bingeing on rice cakes and peanut butter or entire tubs of greek yogurt.

I mean, its not like they are just asking for money, they are selling something and using the money to enrich themselves/support their organization.

And the worst part is individual troops get like 55 cents for every box that they sell.
National is getting greedy with all of the licensing stuff.

Hello fellow Girl Scout!
A lot of troops will let you donate a box of cookies to the local food bank or USO to send to military people stationed overseas. Even if they don't have a program you can always just donate a few bucks and not get cookies, or buy a box and give them to the kid selling them (thats what my grandmother always does).

I am so over seeing gushy Facebook posts about how looking at poor people changed some upper middle class college kid's perspectives (especially when said post is accompanied by pictures of them carrying around a random brown child)
If you want to change the world there are so many poor communities that aren't a multi thousand dollar plane ticket away that could use help. If you want to go to a foreign country and experience the culture just take a vacation, don't do it under the guise of "saving the poor brown people".

Yeah, I have an eating disorder and just get on the scale backwards because I'm not in a place where I feel comfortable seeing my weight. Its not that the number bothers me (it will always be too high) but I get weighed every week and I know that seeing my weight go up or down would not help me eat more and purge less.
